CAPTION FIG1.png: 'Figure 1: SDS-PAGE of pig brain clathrin and its purified components (12.5% gel; Maiael, 1989). Lane 1, purified ddahrin (40 mg); lane 2, heavy chains (20 mg) after separation in 1.3 M NaSCN; lane 3, tryptic heavy chain fragment (5 mg); lane 4, Ld after DEAE-Sephael chromatography (5 mg); lane 5, Ld after DEAE-Sephased chromatography (4 mg); lane 6, light chains after separation in 1.3 M NaSCN (8 mg); lane 7, Ld from preparative SDS-PAGE (5 mg); lane 8, Ld from preparative SDS-PAGE (3 mg). Mol., wts. are shown on the left.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG3.png: 'Figure 3: Electron micrographs of rotary shadowed clathrin (**A**) and heavy chains (**B**). Scale bar \\(=100\\) nm.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG4.png: 'Figure 4: One-dimensional peptide analysis of heavy chains (**A**) and light chains (**B**) from pig brain (PB) and rat liver (RL) performed according to the method of Cleveland _et al._ (1977). Polypeptides excised from a 12.5% polyacrylamide SDS-gel (\\(\\sim\\)10 mg for heavy 5 mg for light chains) were transferred to the sample slots of a second gel (16% for **A**, 20% for **B**) and digested in situ with **S**, aureus V8 protease (0.8 mg per slot for heavy chains and 0.06 mg for light chains). The small amounts of contaminants present in the control rat liver bands run without protease appear very resistant to proteolysis and do not interfere with the analysis. After separation, the fragments were visualized by silver staining as described by Ansorge (1983). Mol. wts. are shown on the left.\n\n'

CAPTION FIG6.png: 'Figure 6: Heavy chain, light chain binding curve. A constant amount of labelled light chains (83 \\(\\pm\\) 8 ng) was incubated for 3 h with increasing amounts of heavy chains in 100 \\(\\mu\\)l buffer and the amount of bound light chains was determined by sedimentation as described in the text. Saturation occurs at \\(\\sim\\)515 \\(\\pm\\) 25 ng of heavy chains.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG7.png: 'Figure 7: Competition of unlabelled L\\(\\alpha\\) and L\\(\\beta\\) light chains with mixtures of labelled L\\(\\alpha\\) + L\\(\\beta\\) in rebinding to heavy chains. For each assay, \\(\\sim\\) 150 ng of heavy chains in 50 ml buffer G were mixed with 50 ml of a solution containing approximately equimolar amounts of labelled L\\(\\alpha\\) + L\\(\\beta\\) (\\(\\sim\\) 25 ng) and variable amounts of unlabelled light chains in buffer F. After incubation for 24 h in the cold, the amount of free labeled light chains was determined as described in Materials and methods. The points of the graph show the percentage of free labelled light chains as a function of increasing amounts of unlabelled light chains; \\(\\Box\\) – competition with L\\(\\alpha\\), \\(\\Box\\) – (L\\(\\beta\\)) and x \\(-\\) (L\\(\\alpha\\) + L\\(\\beta\\)). The curve drawn is that expected if unlabeled and labelled light chains compete for binding with equal efficiency and if heavy chains and labelled light chains are present in equimolar amounts.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG8.png: 'Figure 8: Competition between pig brain and rat liver light chains. **H**-labelled rat liver triskelons were incubated with purified pig brain light chains in the presence of 1.2 M NaSCN for 30 min at 20\\({}^{\\circ}\\)C and then diluted 6 times with buffer C. After 15 min at 20\\({}^{\\circ}\\)C the mixture was centrifuged at 135 000 \\(g\\) for 45 min in an airfuge. Upper (**b**) and lower (**a**) halves of the airfuge tube were analysed by fluorography of SDS-gels. **1,2** control \\(-\\) no NaSCN, no light chains.; **3,4 \\(+\\)**L**_a_; **5,6 \\(+\\)**L**_α_; **7,8** control \\(-\\) NaSCN, no light chains.\n\n'
